aspecttable.name: WM 1980
aspecttable.reference: As described in the 1980 Chessie System Operating Rules.

revision.revremark: Initial version of the signal set.

aspect.name: Approach Diverging
aspect.indication: Proceed approaching next signal prepared to take diverging route.

aspect.name: Diverging Clear
aspect.indication: Proceed through crossovers, turnouts, sidings, interlocking limits, and over power switches at speed specified in special instructions for that location; then proceed at maximum authorized speed.

aspect.name: Approach
aspect.indication: Proceed prepared to stop at next signal. Train or engine exceeding medium speed must take action at or before reaching approach indication to reduce to that speed.

aspect.name: Diverging Approach
aspect.indication: Proceed through crossovers, turnouts, sidings, interlocking limits, and over power switches at speed specified in special instructions for that location; then proceed at not exceeding medium speed prepared to stop at next signal.

aspect.name: Slow Clear
aspect.indication: Proceed; Slow speed through crossovers, turnouts, sidings, interlocking limits, and over power switches; then proceed at maximum authorized speed.

aspect.name: Slow Approach
aspect.indication: Slow speed through crossovers, turnouts, sidings, interlocking limits, and over power switches; then proceed at not exceeding medium speed prepared to stop at next signal.
aspect.comment: The mast signal shown here is a non-standard indication. The rule book shows this as an approach indication. Yet based on David Hughes' article in the WMHS Magazine show it was called Slow Approach and used at Emory Grove for west bound trains crossing over from track 2 to track 1 and entering the Hanover Subdivision. Interestingly westbound trains on track 1 would receive a standard Approach when routed for the Hanover Subdivision.

aspect.name: Stop and Proceed
aspect.indication: Stop; then proceed at restricted speed.
